section.title: If structures (1)
section.sectiontitle: Use the First Conditional to talk about a possible situation in the future. Use the Present Simple, Present Continuous or Present Perfect in the if clause, and the Future or Present Continuous or Imperative + verb in the main clause.
section.text1a: We're going to get very wet if it rains.
section.text2a: I'll give him your message if I see him.
section.sectiontitle2: The 'if clause' can come first or second. When the if clause is first, we need a comma at the end of the clause.
section.text4a: If you haven't finished by 5 p.m., I won't be able to give you a lift home.

section.title: If structures (1)
section.sectiontitle: Use the Second Conditional to talk about unlikely or imagined situations in the present / future. Use If + Past Simple or Past Continuous, would (or 'd) + infinitive.
section.text1a: If I lived in the country, I'd do a lot more walking.
section.text2a: If we had a car, we'd visit my parents more often.
section.sectiontitle2: When we are less certain, we can use might instead of would.
section.text3a: If someone gave me a lot of money, I might take a year off work.
section.text4a: If I got some time off, I might go on holiday.

section.title: If structures (1)
section.sectiontitle: Also, use the Second Conditional to give advice.
section.text1a: I'd buy a good English-English dictionary if I were you.
section.text2a: I wouldn't do that if I were you.

section.title: If structures (1)
section.sectiontitle: Use the Third Conditional to talk about past situations that did not happen. Use If + Past Perfect, would have + past participle.
section.text1: She didn't answer all the questions. She didn't pass the exam.
section.text1a: If she had answered all the questions, she would have passed the exam.
section.text2: I cooked roast chicken. I didn't know they were vegetarian.
section.text2a: I wouldn't have cooked roast chicken if I had known they were vegetarian.
